node.text:
That’s a wrap for the Junior Astronaut Camp! We had a stellar week with 52 curious and engaged young Canadians from across the country who virtually joined our astronauts, engineers and scientists for some exciting space training. 🚀

The camp was a unique opportunity to learn about space careers and the qualities required for a mission to the Moon!

node.title: That’s a wrap for the Junior Astronaut Camp!

node.text:
Our #JuniorAstronauts Camp starts today! 👩‍🚀 52 teens from across Canada will virtually join our astronauts, engineers and scientists.

Participants will be challenged through various activities related to Earth observation, robotics, space kitchen, rovers and working out!

Be sure to look at our Story this week for exclusive behind-the-scenes access!

Video: CSA, ESA

node.title: Junior Astronaut: A message from Thomas Pesquet @thom_astro

node.text:
When seeing our planet from space, astronauts sometimes experience a powerful shift in the way they think about Earth and life. 🌎 What was YOUR moment when you realized the importance of protecting our environment?

This Earth Day, let’s restore our planet. 👆

#EarthDay #EarthDay2021 #SatellitesForEarth #satellite #earthobservation #satellitedata #RCMSatellites #surveillance #environment #climatechange #ecosystem

node.text:
Why do we explore space?🚀 To push the limits of what’s possible. To discover and innovate – and to use what we learn out there to improve our lives back here on Earth.🌎 

A Canadian Space Agency astronaut will be part of Artemis II, an exciting lunar mission that will set a new record: the farthest that humans have ever ventured from Earth. Happy International Day of Human Space Flight!
 
Video: CSA/NASA/Héroux-Devtek

node.text:
The Canadian Arctic is home to over 200,000 people. Travelling on sea ice is an essential part of their lives. But due to climate change, Canada’s North is warming up two to three times faster than the rest of the planet. This causes sea ice to melt, making traditional knowledge of the icescape less reliable. Space technologies – specifically satellites – can help. Meet Polar View, a company that uses Earth observation data to serve the Canadian Arctic.

🎥: CSA; Polar View, Andreas Cziferszky, British Antarctic Survey, C-CORE, Thomas Puestow, Steffen M. Olsen, Danish Meteorological Institute

#SatellitesforEarth
#canadianarctic #canadiannorth #nunavut #satellitedata #earthobservation #eo #satellites #satellite #canada #coastline #earthfromspace

node.text:
Landing on Mars is hard. Only about 40% of the missions ever sent to Mars have been successful.

It takes more than 11 minutes to get a radio signal back from Mars, so by the time the mission team hears that the spacecraft has entered the atmosphere, in reality, the rover is already on the ground… alive… or dead.

NASA's Perseverance Mars Rover will land on Mars on February 18, using the third technique shown in this video. 

Video: NASA/JPL-Caltech

node.text:
The Falcon 9 rocket that launched to the @iss last weekend is one of several modern vehicles being used for space travel.

Learn more about the rockets of today and tomorrow with @astrojeremy.

Video: CSA/NASA/Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center/SpaceX/Virgin Galactic/Blue Origin/Sierra Nevada Corporation

node.title: Rockets – narrated by CSA astronaut Jeremy Hansen

node.text:
Canada has the world’s longest coastline, home to over 7 million people. Coastal areas are constantly evolving and are particularly sensitive to climate change. In order to protect them, it is important to monitor them and better understand those changes over time. A Canadian company called Arctus is doing just that—using satellite data. Learn more: https://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/satellites/everyday-lives/default.asp.

Video: CSA/ESA/Arctus/LDGIZC, UQAR

#coasts #coastalareas #canadiancoast #satellitedata #earthobservation #eo #satellites #satellite #canada #coastline #earthfromspace #space

node.title: Arctus: a Canadian company that uses satellite data

node.text:
Juno: an early version of a rover that could one day be sent to the Moon or to Mars! Learn more about it: https://asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/rovers/mission-simulations/lunar-exploration-analogue-deployment.asp. 

Ask us anything about the CSA’s rovers in our Reddit AMA on November 5 at 1:30 p.m.!

#DareToExplore #canada #canadianexpertise #artificialintelligence #ai #autonomy #moon #spaceexploration #canadian #expertise #innovation #rovers #science #space #technology

node.title: The Juno rover, training to recover samples

node.text:
We all have a role to play in limiting the spread of COVID-19.

No matter where you are, it is crucial to wash your hands properly. If former CSA astronaut @colchrishadfield could do it in space, so can you!

Here are some tips on handwashing: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/reduce-spread-covid-19-wash-your-hands.html.

Video: CSA/NASA

#washyourhands #handwashing #covid19 #covid #coronavirus #covidcanada #canada #space #canadian #astronaut #chrishadfield #spacestation #stayhealthy #health #stopthespread

node.text:
Happy International Chocolate Day from space! 🍫🍰

Food must meet certain criteria to be allowed in orbit. It must be compact, lightweight, nutritious, tasty, and sticky. It is a good thing that chocolate pudding cake fits the bill! 😉

Video: CSA/NASA

#InternationalChocolateDay #SpaceFood #Dessert #ChocolatePuddingCake #Chocolate #ChocolateLover #EatingInSpace #LifeInSpace #Astronaut #ChrisHadfield #TheProofOfThePuddingIsInTheEating

node.text:
Stars age gracefully… and brightly! ✨
This stunning image captures a small region on the edge of the inky Coalsack Nebula, or Caldwell 99. The object at the centre of the image is a protoplanetary nebula. The protoplanetary nebula phase is a late stage in the life of a star in which it has ejected a shell of hydrogen gas and is quickly heating up. After a few thousand years, the protoplanetary nebula’s central star is producing enough energy to make its surrounding shell of gas glow, becoming what’s known as a planetary nebula.

Photo: NASA, ESA, and R. Sahai (Jet Propulsion Laboratory)

#CoalsackNebula #Caldwell99 #Nebula #Stars #LifeOfAStar #ProtoplanetaryNebula #Astronomy #StarGlow #Science

In this image, we challenge you to see the portrait of a man whose features are formed by the lakes, rivers and mountain peaks of the Yukon. As the Yukon’s brand ambassador, Mr. Whitehorse is larger than life!

node.text:
The principal investigator of the Canadian-built elements on the James Webb Space Telescope, professor René Doyon from the Université de Montréal, answered a few of our questions.

🌟 What is your connection to the James Webb Space Telescope?
I am the principal investigator of the Canadian-built instruments on Webb: the Fine Guidance Sensor, which will allow the telescope to point at and focus on objects of interest; and the Near-Infrared Imager and Slitless Spectrograph, which will help study many astronomical objects, from exoplanets to distant galaxies (FGS/NIRISS).

🌟 What part of the Webb mission are you most excited about?
In short, trying to answer this big question: Are we alone? More specifically, studying exoplanets, worlds beyond the solar system that could have the right conditions for life to flourish.

🌟 What advice would you give young people interested in going into space science?
Just believe in it! It's up to you to make your dream come true. Of course, you need to be a little good at math and science in general, but being passionate with a strong desire to do it is all you need. The rest is details, including quite a bit of work, but who cares if you love it!

Images: NASA/JPL-Caltech/R. Hurt (IPAC), NASA/JPL-Caltech, NASA/JPL-Caltech/Ames, NASA/JPL-Caltech

When we take a selfie, we just hold out our arm and snap a photo. To create the first Perseverance rover selfie, it took an entire team of people working together for almost a whole week.

They stitched together 62 images captured by Perseverance’s camera to create this selfie.

Video: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS

Satellite Art #10 – What’s your favourite place in Canada, no matter the time of year? ☀️ 🌸 🍂❄️

The Rideau Lakes of Ontario is an ideal ambassador for the beauty that this province offers in all seasons. Often referred to as “cottage country,” Rideau Lakes has much to offer – from scenic views to rolling hills, wildlife, and a national historic site!

Credit: Kevin R. Jones / CATALYST (PCI Geomatics). Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel-1 data processed by ESA. Landsat 8 data courtesy of the USGS.

#SatelliteArt #RideauLakes #Ontario #Canada #CottageCountry #AllSeasons #CanadianBeauty #CanadianLandscapes

node.text:
Have you ever seen a comet in the night sky? ☄️

Comets are like dirty cosmic snowballs; they are made up of ice, frozen gases, rock and dust, and generally range from a few hundred metres in diameter to tens of kilometres wide. Comets are most often found in the outer solar system, far away from the Sun. But when elliptical orbits occasionally bring them close to the Sun, their ice and frozen gases turn to vapour and form tails behind them.

Photos: ESO/H.H.Heyer, NASA/Marshall Space Flight Center/Aaron Kingery, J. Linder/ESO, ESO/SPECULOOS Team/E. Jehin

node.text:
SPACE FACT 16: Saturn's rings 🪐

#astronomy #planet #saturn #saturnrings #solarsystem

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Canadian Space Agency on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'SPACE FACT SATURN'S RINGS 16 Photo: NASA'.

Photo by Canadian Space Agency on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Saturn is best known for its impressive rings, which are about 20 metres thick on average. Some scientists believe that the planet's icy rings are made of material left over from one of its early moons. Pho:NASA Photo:'.

Photo by Canadian Space Agency on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'They are not solid: each one is made up of 90% to 95% water ice. Each ring contains small particles that can range in size from a speck of dust to a 10- metre-wide snowball! Photo: NASA'.

Photo by Canadian Space Agency on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The entire system stretches up to 282,000 kilometres from the planet Each ring orbits the planet at a different speed. Photo:NASA'.
Photo by Canadian Space Agency on September 02, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Visit our page for more Space Facts!'.
